item.title: By: Pierre
item.dc:creator: Pierre
item.description:
I've often thought of what if any effect the study of Eastern interaction with Western thought in the Jewish and Greek-Philosophical exchange. I've asked academics about the following resources, as with Heidegger and Buddhism, but even in the 21st century among students whom I think would be interested, mention of such research receives blank expressions as if I'd resuscitated "Black Athena" and implication that the 'mesorah' of ideas and concepts only seems to matter from the point when a Jew or a European thinks it;
"Eastern Influences on Western Philosophy; A Reader" by Macfie
"Oriental Enlightenment; The Encounter Between Asian and Western Thought".
"The Shape of Ancient Thought" by Mcevilley
item.content:encoded:
I’ve often thought of what if any effect the study of Eastern interaction with Western thought in the Jewish and Greek-Philosophical exchange. I’ve asked academics about the following resources, as with Heidegger and Buddhism, but even in the 21st century among students whom I think would be interested, mention of such research receives blank expressions as if I’d resuscitated “Black Athena” and implication that the ‘mesorah’ of ideas and concepts only seems to matter from the point when a Jew or a European thinks it;

“Eastern Influences on Western Philosophy; A Reader” by Macfie

“Oriental Enlightenment; The Encounter Between Asian and Western Thought”.

“The Shape of Ancient Thought” by Mcevilley
